text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised text for IRM 4.26.15, Bank Secrecy Act, General Program.

IRM 4.26.15.1 added to conform to the new internal control requirements described in IRM 1.11.2, Internal Controls. The information formerly in this section titled Overview was moved to Program Scope and Objectives.
IRM 4.26.15.2 name changed to Required Filing Checks General Guidelines to better reﬂect contents. Content was updated and links added to material in other IRM sections.
4.26.15.5.2 deleted and information included in 4.26.15.5.
Removed Exhibit 4.26.15-1, Comparison of Form 8938 and FBAR Requirements, as information can be found on irs.gov. Link provided in IRM 4.26.15.6.3. Added BSA Referral Decision Matrix as an
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This supersedes IRM 4.26.15 dated November 4, 2015.
Intended audience is employees of the Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE) division and can be referenced by all ﬁeld compliance personnel.
Table of Contents
Bank Secrecy Act Referral Decision Matrix
page (
) Purpose. This IRM describes administrative procedures and audit that should be used by the general program income tax examiner working a case related to BSA. (
) Audience. This IRM is for general income tax examiners, but may be refer- enced by Specialty BSA and all other divisions of the IRS. (
) Policy Owner. Director, Specialty Examination Policy – Small Business/Self Employed. (
) Program Owner. Director, Examination - Specialty Examination owns Bank Secrecy Act. (
) Contact Information. To recommend changes or make any other related to this IRM section, see IRM
, Providing Feedback About an IRM Section - Outside of Clearance. (
) Program Goals. The general program examiner should be aware of the mation available on the Fi
EN Query System (FCQ), as well as the basic ﬁling requirements of both the Bank Secrecy Act (BSA) and IRC
I, Returns Relating to Cash Received in Trade or Business, etc. Examiners also keep Title
(BSA) and Title
(IRC) activities separate. (
) Authority for the IRS to conduct BSA examinations includes the following sources: a.
USC
(a), General Powers of Secretary, provides the Secretary the Treasury with authority to administer provisions of the BSA. b.
CFR
), Enforcement, gives the Commissioner, IRS, delegated authority to examine certain ﬁnancial institutions to compliance with BSA requirements. c. A Memorandum of Agreement dated April
delegates and penalty authority for Foreign Bank Account Reports (FBARs) from the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (Fi
EN) to the IRS. See IRM
, FBAR Delegation to IRS. d. A Memorandum of Understanding and Delegation of Authority to Non-Financial Trades and Businesses, dated April
, delegates examination authority under Title
for Form
, Report of Cash Payments Over $
Received in a Trade or Business, from to the IRS. See IRM
, Form
Title
Delegation to IRS. e. Related authority: IRC
, Canvass of Districts for Taxable Persons and Objects, Authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to Inquire into Taxpayers’ Tax Liability. IRC
, Examination of Books and Authorizes the Secretary to Examine Books and Witnesses for Speciﬁc Purposes Including Determining and Collecting Federal Tax Liabilities. (
) See IRM
Bank Secrecy Act, Introduction and Program Structure. (

) Director, Examination – Specialty Examination is the executive responsible BSA examination operational compliance.

) The local BSA group manager can be a resource person for questions about BSA program policies and procedures. A Title

) FCQ information is useful in identifying cash activity that may not be reported on the income tax return. In addition, it may lead the examiner to discover sources of unreported income, often derived from criminal activity. FCQ information is a “window” into the underground economy, with information not obtainable elsewhere. (
) SB/SE has limited access to the Fi
EN Portal to Fi
EN Super Users in Exam. Each state has a Subject Matter Expert (SME) to which the agent will submit their request. A list of Fi
EN Super Users for Exam can be found at: (

) Access and use of FCQ data is subject to managerial review of audit trails to ensure appropriate use of FCQ data in relation to assigned cases. a. Managerial reviews of audit trails will be conducted on an annual basis and may be conducted in conjunction with annual workload reviews. b. A
-day period will be selected from the prior
months of FCQ c. Queries will be compared against open inventory for the same

-day period or will be validated through other business controls (such as keeper procedures) to ensure queries were related to assigned cases. d. A required second-level review would normally be conducted during an operational review. (
) Examiners should refer to IRM
, Fi
EN Query (FCQ), for detailed mation on FCQ.
SBSE has Subject Matter Experts (SME) who can be contacted for Information can be found at http://mysbse.web.irs.gov/SME/default.aspx.
(01-13-2021) FinCEN Query (FCQ) Use in Title 26 Examinations
a. Managerial reviews of audit trails will be conducted on an annual basis and may be conducted in conjunction with annual workload reviews. b. A
-day period will be selected from the prior
months of FCQ activity. c. Queries will be compared against open inventory for the same

-day period or will be validated through other business controls (such as gate- keeper procedures) to ensure queries were related to assigned cases. d. A required second-level review would normally be conducted during an operational review.
) Access to BSA information through FCQ for tax purposes is governed by Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between the Financial Crimes ment Network (Fi

See IRM

) The MOU allows compliance employees electronic access to SAR or the ability to receive SAR data when authorized by their operating and business unit leaders. (
) SAR information requests are limited to active examination and collection cases and case-building activities. (
) Training on SAR information access and security is mandatory prior to any thorized access. For a full discussion of SAR access and security, see IRM
, Disclosure. Also see IRM

) If, in the course of a BSA examination, the BSA examiner identiﬁes and/or businesses conducting questionable transactions in currency and/or monetary instruments that indicate possible violations, a referral for an nation may be appropriate. No related statute determination is necessary to transmit Title
information for Title
action. (
) The BSA examination program generates leads from sources such as: a. Title
BSA and Form
examinations, b. Criminal Investigation referrals, and c. CTR Operations- Detroit. (
) These information leads are forwarded to the ﬁeld for possible income tax aminations on Form
, Examination Information Report or Form
, Criminal Investigation Information Item. (
) An income tax examination based on a referral from a BSA examination is conducted in accordance with established procedures for income tax tions. (
) The BSA examiner must not be assigned to the income tax examination. (
) Income tax examinations resulting from the BSA program are assigned the following project codes: •
— Leads from the Form
program •
— Leads from the Title
program (
) If fraud is discovered as part of an income tax examination and the case is updated to status
, the project code should be changed to reﬂect the issue: • From

USC

(g), Reporting of Suspicious Transactions, the examiner must not: a. Disclose that a SAR report has been ﬁled, b. Propose an adjustment based solely on an amount listed on a Investigation Information Item (Form

), c. Disclose a source or possible source of the information, d. Conduct the examination in a way the taxpayer could reasonably conclude any of the above, or e. Issue a summons for speciﬁc SAR information. (

a. Transactions occurred which involved the receipt of cash in excess of $
b. There were consecutive or related transactions in excess of $

When Form 8300 violations are discovered or suspected in a Title 26 case, the Title 26 examiner may examine the taxpayer’s Form 8300 compliance under Title 26 without violating Title 26 disclosure rules. The agent should discuss ﬁndings with their Group Manager to determine whether to continue to develop the Form 8300 issues that have been identiﬁed during the case or whether to make a referral to BSA. See the Bank Secrecy Act Referral Decision Matrix at Exhibit 4.26.15-1.

) If the agent determines, with management concurrence, to continue to the Form
issues, the agent will need to set up a separate case ﬁle for Form
examination. This is separate from the income tax examination case ﬁle and time will be applied to the Form
case for work completed. The Form
case should be established on ERCS. a. Form
cases are set up in ERCS under MFT “PX”, “Year”, “Name entity” and “EIN”. b. Project code
with the appropriate tracking code should be placed on all established cases. (
) Examiners must request to stop Form
correspondence so that BSA pliance Department, Detroit does not send a penalty letter to a ﬁler that has already been audited by a ﬁeld examiner. See IRM
, Stopping respondence. (

and IRM

Industries, for guidance on setting up, working and closing the Form
case. (

should be prepared and sent to BSA Exam Case Selection for consideration for a Form
compliance exam. The Form

should as complete and accurate as possible. The agent needs to ensure the legal name and Tax Identiﬁcation Number are provided to BSA ECS for case building purposes. The agent should summarize all Form
issues

) Special considerations apply to FBAR violations. (
) Foreign accounts are commonly discovered during a Title
tax case. Examiners can consult FCQ to verify if the taxpayer ﬁled a Fi
EN Form Report of Foreign Bank and Financial Accounts (FBAR). in a Title
) Foreign assets or accounts may also trigger a Form
, Statement of Speciﬁed Foreign Financial Assets ﬁling requirement. Form
, is a requirement, not a BSA requirement. A comparison of Form
and requirements may be found at: form-
-and-fbar-requirements. (

) BSA does not accept referrals for FBAR examinations. Each operating is responsible for examining its own FBAR cases. The case examiner discovers the suspected FBAR violation has the greatest knowledge of facts of the case and is expected to address the FBAR issue. (
) The Title
taxpayer cannot be examined for suspected FBAR violations unless an RSD has been made. The taxpayer should not be questioned regarding FBAR compliance until the RSD is made. See IRM
, of Foreign Bank and Financial Accounts (FBAR) Procedures. (
) For assistance in working FBAR cases, see IRM
